title: 112_hr6659
content: The "Urban Recovery and Growth Act" is cited as the short title. It extends the Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds for certain cities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Urban Recovery and Growth Act" extends the Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds by treating them as qualified bonds issued before January 1, 2011, increasing the applicable percentage to 45%, and making interest on the bonds taxable. An economic development extension bond is defined as a specified bond issued within a 1-year period after the enactment of the section. An economic development extension bond is any specified bond issued within a 1-year period after the enactment of the section, with certain conditions regarding project proceeds and reserve amounts. An economic development extension bond is a specified bond issued within a 1-year period after the enactment of the section, where 100 percent of the excess project proceeds over required reserves must be used for qualified purposes, and the issuer must designate the bond for this purpose. The specified bond, excluding private activity bonds, allows for tax-exempt interest under section 103. The specified bond, excluding private activity bonds, allows for tax-exempt interest under section 103. Any obligation where the interest would be excludable from gross income under section 103 is subject to applicable rules similar to section 54AA(d)(2) and section 148 does not apply if the excess is used for a qualified purpose. The specified bond, excluding private activity bonds, allows for tax-exempt interest under section 103. Section 54AA(d)(2) applies, and section 148 does not apply if the excess is used for a qualified economic development purpose as defined in section 1400U-2(c). The term 'qualified purposes' includes qualified economic development purposes and refinancing of indebtedness for specified cities. A 'specified city' is a principal city in a metropolitan statistical area designated by the Office of Management and Budget. The term 'specified city' refers to a principal city in a metropolitan statistical area with high unemployment and significant job losses. This includes refinancing of existing debt for these cities. The term 'specified city' refers to a principal city in a metropolitan statistical area with high unemployment and significant job losses. These cities must meet specific criteria to qualify for designated bonds, including high unemployment rates and population loss between 2000 and 2010. There is a limitation on the amount of bonds that can be designated for these cities. The specified city must meet criteria such as high unemployment and population loss between 2000 and 2010 to qualify for designated bonds. There is a limitation on the maximum aggregate face amount of bonds that can be designated for each city. The Secretary allocates bond limitations to specified cities based on their population proportion to $1,000,000,000. The bond limitation allocated to a city is based on its population proportion to $1,000,000,000 as determined by the 2010 census. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter Y of chapter 1 of the Code. Extension of recovery zone economic development bonds for certain cities, with amendments applying to obligations issued after the enactment of this Act.
